pullRequest.body:
This unbundles the unit and counit components from `Quiv.adj` and proves they equal the previously defined (pre)functors `Paths.of` and `pathComposition`. The unbundled `Quiv.adj` adjunction data is used to golf the construction of `ReflQuiv.adj`.

---

I am not confident I've named the unbundled terms in `Quiv.lean` correctly. For the most part, I reused the names of existing `Quiv.adj` dot projections (which is why various defs are labelled "non-recursive"). One exception is `adj.counit.naturality_eq`. I previously tried calling this `adj.counit.naturality` but then I had trouble calling this version of the lemma; instead it called the dot notation version.

Is overloading term names really a good idea or should I use primes or similar? Note when I tried `adj.counit.naturality'` for what is now called `adj.counit.naturality_eq` this returned an error saying that `naturality'` is not a field of `adj.counit`.

One thing inhibited the desired use of these terms in the gofling of `ReflQuiv.adj`. In verifying the left triangle identity there, I start with `ext V` which gives me a `V : ReflQuiv`. It would be more useful to have the unbundled version of this `V`. Is that possible?

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

### PR summary [070348dae1](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/22443/commits/070348dae1bea58c342d9a57bd2e9e82fc780b78)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ freeMap`
`+ freeMapCompIso`
`+ freeMapIdIso`
`+ freeMapPathsOfCompPathCompositionIso`
`+ freeMap_comp`
`+ freeMap_id`
`+ freeMap_pathsOf_pathComposition`
`+ freeMap_pathsOf_pathComposition'`
`+ freeReflMap`
`+ freeReflMap_naturality`
`+ mapPath_comp_apply`
`+ mapPath_id`
`+ ofCatHom`
`+ ofQuivHom`
`+ of_toCatHom`
`+ of_toQuivHom`
`+ pathComposition_naturality`
`+ pathsEquiv`
`+ pathsOf_pathComposition_toPrefunctor`
`+ toCatHom`
`+ toQuivHom`
`+ to_ofCatHom`
`+ to_ofQuivHom`
`- freeRefl_naturality`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Have a look at the cascading changes resulting from making the argument of `Paths.of` explicit. Let me know if you want me to revert back to an implicit argument.

I think the definition of `free` should use this definition, and others:
```lean
/-- A prefunctor `V ⥤q W` induces a functor between the path categories defined by `F.mapPath`. -/
@[simps]
def freeMap {V W : Type*} [Quiver V] [Quiver W] (F : V ⥤q W) :
  Paths V ⥤ Paths W where
    obj := F.obj
    map := F.mapPath
    map_comp f g := F.mapPath_comp f g

@[simps!]
def freeMapIdIso (V : Type*) [Quiver V] :
    freeMap (𝟭q V) ≅ 𝟭 _ :=
  NatIso.ofComponents (fun _ ↦ Iso.refl _)

def freeMap_id (V : Type*) [Quiver V] :
    freeMap (𝟭q V) = 𝟭 _ :=
  Functor.ext_of_iso (freeMapIdIso V) (fun _ ↦ rfl) (fun _ ↦ rfl)

universe v₁ v₂ v₃ u₁ u₂ u₃ 

@[simps!]
def freeMapCompIso {V₁ : Type u₁} {V₂ : Type u₂} {V₃ : Type u₃}
    [Quiver.{v₁ + 1} V₁] [Quiver.{v₂ + 1} V₂] [Quiver.{v₃ + 1} V₃]
    (F : V₁ ⥤q V₂) (G : V₂ ⥤q V₃) :
    freeMap (F ⋙q G) ≅ freeMap F ⋙ freeMap G :=
  NatIso.ofComponents (fun _ ↦ Iso.refl _) (fun f ↦ by
    dsimp
    simp only [Category.comp_id, Category.id_comp]
    -- the goal here should be made a simp lemma
    induction f with
    | nil => rfl
    | cons _ _ h => simp [h])

def freeMap_comp {V₁ : Type u₁} {V₂ : Type u₂} {V₃ : Type u₃}
    [Quiver.{v₁ + 1} V₁] [Quiver.{v₂ + 1} V₂] [Quiver.{v₃ + 1} V₃]
    (F : V₁ ⥤q V₂) (G : V₂ ⥤q V₃) :
    freeMap (F ⋙q G) = freeMap F ⋙ freeMap G :=
  Functor.ext_of_iso (freeMapCompIso F G)
    (fun _ ↦ rfl) (fun _ ↦ rfl)

/-- The functor sending each quiver to its path category. -/
@[simps]
def free : Quiv.{v, u} ⥤ Cat.{max u v, u} where
  obj V := Cat.of (Paths V)
  map F := Functor.toCatHom (freeMap (Prefunctor.ofQuivHom F))
  map_id _ := freeMap_id _
  map_comp _ _ := freeMap_comp _ _
```
(Note that it is possible to prove an equality of functors *after* we have proved there was an isomorphism. This way, in downstream uses, depending on the needs, we can use the equality of functors, or the isomorphism, with quite good definitional properties.)

There is no need for an auxiliary definition here:
```lean
@[simp]
lemma adj_unit_app_of (V : Type u) [Quiver.{max u v + 1} V] :
    adj.unit.app (Quiv.of V) = Paths.of := rfl
```

That this one is not a definitional equality suggest that the adjunction should be defined in terms of the `unit` and the `counit` rather than `Adjunction.mkOfHomEquiv`. If it were defined using the unit and counit (`Paths.of` and `pathComposition`), we would get an adjunction with better definitional properties.
(For a typical adjunction between categories, we would usually not care too much about the definitional properties of `unit` and `counit`, but here, these (co)units are functors rather than "just maps", so that I think we should care about it.)
Then, I think that the left/right triangle lemmas should be written in the following fashion:
```lean
def freeMapPathsOfCompPathCompositionIso (V : Type u) [Quiver.{max u v + 1} V] :
    Cat.freeMap (Paths.of (V := V)) ⋙
      pathComposition (Cat.of (Paths V)) ≅ 𝟭 (Paths V) :=
  NatIso.ofComponents (fun _ ↦ Iso.refl _) sorry

lemma freeMap_pathsOf_pathComposition (V : Type u) [Quiver.{max u v + 1} V] :
    Cat.freeMap (Paths.of (V := V)) ⋙
      pathComposition (Cat.of (Paths V)) = 𝟭 (Paths V) :=
  Functor.ext_of_iso (freeMapPathsOfCompPathCompositionIso V) (fun _ ↦ rfl)
    (fun _ ↦ rfl)
```
Then, the adjunction can be defined as:
```lean
def adj : Cat.free ⊣ Quiv.forget where
  unit := { app X := Paths.of }
  counit :=
    { app X := pathComposition X
      naturality := sorry }
  left_triangle_components X := freeMap_pathsOf_pathComposition _
  right_triangle_components := sorry
```
After that, if it is necessary, it would be possible to give equational lemmas for the `homEquiv` field of `adj`.
(Note: the parameter of `Paths.of` should probably be made explicit.)

I reconstructed `adj` as suggested and it's much better this way! Great suggestion.

But for both `freeMap_pathsOf_pathComposition` and the other triangle identity I actually found it easiest to prove the equality directly (see `freeMap_pathsOf_pathComposition'`) because:

* there's a great `Paths.ext_functor`
* the use of `Functor.ext_of_iso` (which I'm very happy to know about) seems less efficient for natural transformations valued in `Cat` (or similar) because naturality still requires a proof of equality between functors.

Let me know which version of `freeMap_pathsOf_pathComposition` you want me to keep.
It seems the name should be `to_ofCatHom`.

The name 
```
to_ofQuivHom {C D : Quiv} (F : C ⟶ D) : toQuivHom (ofQuivHom F) = F 
```
seems more intuitive for me too but I was following the pattern I see in
```
of_α (C) [Category C] : (of C).α = C := rfl
```
which suggests the functions should be named in diagrammatic order `first_second`?

pullRequest.title: feat(Category Theory): unbundled quiver adjunction data
